item.title: End of Semester 2
item.description:
It’s been a while since I posted anything - semester 2 got away from me a little bit. I thought I would post to sum up how the semester 2 classes went. And reflect a bit on what I am currently working on.

Semester 2

I was involved in teaching two classes this semester: Mathematical and Statistical Computing and Spatial Statistics. Both of these have had feedback collected, so I’m using this to reflect on how the semester went and what changes can and should be made to reflect the comments.

Mathematical and Statistical Computing

Mathematical and Statistical computing is an introductory programming class (using R) delivered to second year Maths and stats undergraduate students. This course is usually particularly challenging because it is different to any other classes that they have taken before. I made the decision to be upfront about this. In the introductory session of the class I said that they should expect to find the class hard, and they might feel as though they are struggling, but to keep pushing and asking questions.

My colleague and I also decided to spread the materials over more weeks than was given for the MSc students in semester 1, so that they had more time to process the typical threshold concepts (loops - everybody hates loops!) This was definitely wise and the students seemed to appreciate this.

The feedback for the class was overall very positive. They felt able to ask questions where they were struggling (which was the goal) and gradually got more independent as the weeks went on. This was really nice to see - I actively encouraged using google and stack exchange as a resource since I knew it would be impossible for me to personally teach every single aspect of R for every possible application. I also wanted them to develop the search engine skills to solve problems on their own. This started out as a grumble, but the students got quite comfortable with it quite quickly.

The key criticism of the course was the desire for more video content. I suspect that this was from students who did not attend the live session (although I have no way of knowing that for sure). In the live session I took the key difficult points that were identified in the tutorial session or through student feedback and discussed problems that were relevant to them. These sessions were recorded and placed on the class page, but did not get a huge number of views.

Spatial Statistics (Face-to-Face)

Spatial statistics is designed to give MSc students an insight into analysing spatial data. I am going to be putting this online for a cohort starting in May, so I was filming for that in time to get the videos online for the face to face version. I didn’t want to duplicate effort, but that was definitely an intense few weeks!

Students usually find this course quite challenging, so I designed it in a fairly structured way that would help to scaffold towards them being able to do a full data analysis. The theoretical concepts were always delivered first via video. Then the methods for applying the theory (in R) were delivered via sets of notes which additionally contained short programming exercises and quizzes. Following this there would be an interactive video where I would demonstrate the code on a data set and ask them to think about their interpretation of the data (which I would then discuss in the video). Then each week they would peform an analysis on spatial data within a supported tutorial session (via Zoom). This was then discussed in more detail in a live session the following week.

The class got probably the best feedback I’ve ever had. Students appreciated the content that was given and found the explanations really useful. They commented specifically on my use of the VLE being varied and interesting.

The key aspects for development based on this were to provide additional description of the context in which you would use the analysis techniques. I did this at the time via forum posts in the weekly Q&A forums, and will build this into future iterations of the class.

Current Work

I am going to be delivering both of these classes in the near future for different audiences. I’m delivering an introductory R class as CPD starting in April, and delivering Spatial Statistics online starting in mid-May to a small cohort of online MSc students.

Introduction to Programming in R (CPD)

This will run with roughly the same materialas before. It is anticipated that this will run entirely online, so I will be thinking about how to present the live sessions that I would have done face-to-face.

I will try to run a weekly drop in session, but may also make the tutorial sheet something that is submitted, so that I can provide some discussion around key mistakes.

Spatial Statistics (Online)

The materials for this will be almost identical to those developed for the face-to-face version of the class. The key difference is that the tutorial material for the face-to-face students will become a student submission which I will provide feedback on. For small class sizes, this will be individual, but as class sizes grow, this will be more general feedback to the entire class.

I may re-evaluate this in the future if I can find a satisfactory way of giving detailed feedback to each student.

item.title: New Year, New Classes
item.description:
Following a slightly extended Christmas break, I’ve returned to work feeling refreshed. This semester is going to be (if possible) even busier than last. In Scotland we’ve been placed back into lockdown, and no-one is particularly sure when it will be lifted.

I wasn’t as active with this as I had hoped last semester - there seemed to be too much going on and I admittedly found myself a bit overwhelmed. Admittedly not helped by the fact that I didn’t leave the house which was predictably not great from a mental health perspective! However new year new me - I’ve decided to commute from home to home by going for a walk before and after work and I’m optimistic that I’ll keep up with this blog a bit more regularly.

I have a lot going on this semester. I’ve noted the key teaching related items below.

Introduction to R (modification for 2nd Year Undergraduates)

For the first half of this semester I’ll be modifying the material that I created for the MSc students last semester so that it is more appropriate for second year undergraduate students.

The key change here is to give the younger students more time and support to process information (particularly the concepts that people tend to find difficult). To that end, this material is being delivered over 7 weeks instead of 6.

I’ve decided to keep the key structures in place so the bulk of the materials will be text resources that students can use as a reference. Each of these resources will have some associated embedded exercises that represent a minimum level of knowledge. There will be a quiz at the end of each week to allow students to test their knowledge. Each week I will ask students to reflect on their learning, and specifically think about what they have found easy and what they have found to be challenging.

There will be two live sessions each week. One will be run as a tutorial/computer lab, making use of Zoom breakout rooms - this was identified as being particularly useful last semester, so I didn’t want to change this. The other live session will be either a drop in session, or a worked example session. This will be decided based on student needs - if students identify particular areas of concern, then these sessions will be used to go over this material live so that students have the opportunity to ask questions. If no key areas are identified then I will use this time as a virtual office hours where students can drop in and ask any questions that they might have.

Introduction to R (modification for CPD)

I’ve also been asked to modify my Introduction to R materials to form a CPD course. The majority of the MSc content can remain as is. The key consideration here is how to deliver the tutorial content - I am undecided as to whether this should be fully online, or whether there should be synchronous sessions.

The advantage to it being fully asynchronous is that participants can fit the course around their schedules more easily. Howeverm part of the fun of CPD is that you meet other people, so in that sense it would be nice to have some form of contact with the participants.

This is due in April, so I have plenty of time to consider exactly how I want to approach this.

Spatial Statistics (Both fully online and Blended)

I’ve just started the process of developing the Spatial Statistics course (this is the class that I’ve taught the longest - starting when I was in the final year of my PhD!) for our online MSc in Applied Statistics in Health Sciences. This is useful since I’ll be teaching this largely online starting in 5 weeks’ time.

I’m currently in the planning stage of this but I have a general idea of how I want the content to look. There are essentially three parts to each topic - The Theory Bit, The Programming Bit and The Example. I want these to take a fairly consistent form as described below. Each week will also contain an exercise for students to work through completely independently, general solutions to this will be provided either as aset of notes, or via video.

The Theory Bit

I want all theoretical aspects of the course to be delivered via video. I personally find it easier to express concepts when I can point to things, or circle things. Video is the best medium for this. Each video will be supported by a set of slides, so that students have something that is easy to look back on.

The Programming Bit

I’ve found that programming is easiest to describe via text, with code snippets included. For this particular aspect, I think that students are likely to want to refer back to materials which is much easier in text than in a video. For this I also want the text to follow the process, so this will also contain a reiteration of some of the theoretical aspects, but in less depth than the videos.

These will include short, simple programming exercises so that there is an opportunity to practice the various aspects of programming independently.

The Example

For each “chunk” of content, there will be an example. I want this to be an opportunity for active learning, so I have decided that I would like these aspects of the classto be interactive videos. I will guide the students through the process via video, but ask questions throughout so that they are thinking about the interpretation as we go through. Essentially this is the High-tech version of “Pause the video and think about this for a minute”.

I did have a couple of interactive videos in my course last semester. These were very well received, so I’m hoping that students will find these interactive videos just as useful.

item.title: Part 1 Reflection
item.description:
The first half is finished, so the new material is all online and the assessment has been completed. I wanted to take a bit of time to reflect on my experiences (the good and the bad) and take a look at what could be improved. I had hoped to be able to post here more often, but these past few weeks have been a complete whirlwind, and I don’t think I’ve ever been so busy/stressed/exhausted.

The Good

Having spoken to the students and looked at the weekly reflections and the Q&A forums, it genuinely seems that students have had an overall positive experience learning how to program with R. In general that students have engaged well with the materials and I’ve been asked some really interesting questions along the way. I’ve outlined some of the specific things that were highlighted by students as being particularly useful.

Notes over video

A large portion of the content for part 1 of the class was developed as a set of notes using R Markdown. These were provided as online resources initially with embedded programming exercises and questions, then provided a pdf version of the same notes (minus the interactive elements) so that students had an offline version of the materials.

Students enjoyed these because it was easy to refer back to them, and these were detailed enough for the majority of students. Some students had also highlighted that they found the videos difficult to watch because of issues with text size (my oversight) and issues with internet connection, so they appreciated having content that was reasonably low tech.

Activities

The programming exercises were highlighted as being really useful as tests for what they had just learned. Given that this was my intention with these activities I’m really pleased that these were flagged as having been useful. One small negative about these is that, since the submission correctness tests can be reasonably complex to program, I tried to keep these simple, and have them act as a baseline for what was needed. I tried to emphasise this to the students, and suggest that the tutorial questions were of a difficulty level comparable to real-world practice. However, there seemed to be some misunderstanding here and the students indicated that the assessment was more difficult than they were anticipating.

One other thing to mention about the programming exercises is that the datacamp lite tool that I had been using could not be used for the tidyverse and ggplot weeks, since the tidyverse packages are out of date. I tried to package the tutorials, but ran into some technical issues (the source markdown documents ran perfectly but they didn’t run when called from the package). Students found this a bit irritating, and I’m hoping to have an alternative method of running these tutorials in place soon!

Tutorials

Students highlighted the tutorials as being the most useful aspect of the course, and I entirely believe that this was true. The idea behind this course design was that it would effectively be a flipped classroom done online, and it seems like that is exactly what happened. I do think that I owe some credit to the two PhD tutors who helped out with this, because they were really engaged and enthusiastic, and I think it takes a certain type of person to be able to do that on Zoom, so I don’t think that the tutorials would have been so successful without them.

The Bad

“The Bad” is probably a bit of an exaggeration, “suggested improvements” would probably be more appropriate but it doesn’t quite have the same ring to it. Below are some of the things that students highlighted as needing improvement.

Quizzes

The quizzes were highlighted as being fairly inflexible when inputting code. This is unfortunately not something that can be helped at the moment, since I have to use a string comparison within the MyPlace quizzes, rather than a code checker (like CodeRunner). I’ve been told that CodeRunner is in the pipeline, but that it requires additional testing. I’ll also need to work out how to use CodeRunner with R, which is not particularly straightforward from what I’ve seen so far!

Live Material

Students wanted more live content, and felt that a code-along type thing might be useful. This was recommended based on a Python class which runs in parallel to my class. However, I’m also told that this class breaks down into smaller groups so that a code-along type activity is easier to manage. I’m going to run a “worked example” session which will be purely based on student feedback. I did this type of session for students just before the test and it went really well, and students definitely engaged with it and asked a lot of questions. The plan is that if enough students ask for this type of session then I’ll run it, and if not I’ll run a drop-in session as planned. If this is successful then I’ll implement it in my classes next semester.

A couple of comments indicated that recorded tutorial solutions and worked examples would be more useful than the note versions, though this type of comment was very much in the minority. I personally disagree that recorded materials here would be more useful, my intuition says that it would be easier for the student to just watch me explain things and decide that they understood everything. With notes I think that, if studied properly, it is easier to pick up on things that don’t make sense and explore this further.

Additional Scaffolding

This isn’t based on student feedback, this is based on my own observations of the class at work. It seems that a lot of students are happy and appear to know what they’re doing and that’s great. However I did notice that those students who did not come from a technical background were being left behind in a lot of areas. This is something that I need to fix, and this is something that will take a bit of time. When I learned R I already had some programming experience, so I’ll need to take a step back and think about how to scaffold some of the more difficult concepts (loops in particular!) and be more specific in my thought process if I were going through the process from the beginning.

This was also flagged as an issue when using some statistical concepts which draw on knowledge from other courses. This is easier to fix, and I plan on adding additional materials on particular statistical processes to improve this aspect.

Going Forward

I don’t feel like I need to make any major changes to the corse as it stands. Overall it was very well received by the students. I think the most major concern that needs to be addressed is the additional scaffolding material for those students who don’t have previous programming (or statistical) experience. I’ll be able to make a start on this over the next couple of weeks.

I’m interested to see how the “worked example” sessions go, and this will probably be my next post. I still want to play along with the idea of a live code-along, but need to work out how this can be done in an efficient way. The key thing here seemed to be the idea of being able to ask for help on errors live, so I think that if I can come up with a nice way of doing this then that could be really useful. I’ll keep an eye out for inspiration on that!

item.title: Week 1 & 2 Reflection
item.description:
The first 2 weeks are done, with far less tech issues than anticipated. I just wanted to take some time to reflect on how it has gone so far.

Positives

The positives greatly outweigh the negatives which is a very nice position to be in. This is based on my overall impression of how it’s gone, as well as the weekly feedback from the students.

Engagement

From the start the students have been really engaged with the materials which I think makes this whole experience that bit more positive for everyone. I’ve had amazing attendance at the mandatory sessions so far which is great. Even going beyond that students have been willing to chat and ask questions and have videos on during the live Zoom sessions (which is a huge relief - I don’t know how I would have manages with a sea of blank squares staring at me).

Much to my surprise the forums have been pretty well used too, with students helping to answer each others’ questions. The class is a mixture of abilities, so this is something that’s really nice to see. The students were also randomly allocated to tutorial groups and have taken really well to working together during these sessions.

The engagement was down a bit last week - I’m hoping that it will pick back up again, and it does seem to be picking up a bit for week 3.

Activities

The embedded programming exercises have been really well received, and students highlighted these as having been really useful for identifying the small things that they haven’t picked up on right away. This was exactly my intention with these so I’m really pleased that that has come through and worked as anticipated. I’ve tried to keep these simple - both for ease of solution checking and to provide the students with a baseline expectation. The idea is that the exercises provided within the activities will be the minimum that they should know. The tutorial questions then build on this and provide the students with a more difficult set of questions that the students can answer in a more flexible way.

The quizzes have been similarly highlighted as being useful, though perhaps a little too straightforward. I think I will need to emphasise the idea of the on MyPlace stuff being a baseline, with the tutorials being the ideal level of knowledge.

Tutorials

I expected there to be technical issues with running these live sessions, but it actually went very smoothly last week, which was great. The students highlighted that they found the live tutorial sessions useful, since they were able to discuss the problems with the other students, and were able to get help from the class tutors.

Not so positives

Within the feedback and based on some of the questions that I was being asked, there are some things around the course that need to be addressed. This is something that I expected, and I’m thankful that I’m getting such valuable feedback.

Wanting More

The main theme of the suggested improvements was around students wanting more - more examples, more exercises etc. This has highlighted areas that need to be developed, and areas that I will need to add additional detail to. I’ll add these to my to-do list and work through the additions over the next few days and weeks.

The key thing that students wanted more of was exercises so I’m trying to keep that in mind as I start to develop materials for the upcoming week.

Going Forward

It seems like going forward I just need to keep doing what I’ve been doing…but more!

This week I ran into a minor snag - I’ve been using Datacamp Lite to run my interactive programming exercises, but the version of the tidyverse packages are not up to date. So I’ve had to workaround this…without a suitably protected server being available at the university yet. I’ve had to make a package of tutorial exercises. My first ever package…how exciting!

item.title: It's Nearly Showtime
item.description:
We’ve just entered week 0 (the induction week) of the semester here at Strathclyde, and I’ve been working more than usual trying to get good quality content online for the upcoming semester. The first two weeks’ worth of material is ready to go but there’s still 8 weeks left to do - I’m definitely not kidding myself that this semester is going to be straightforward.

This is going to be a reasonably short post, but i’m going to pin point some things that I’ve been doing over the past few weeks (some of which to help the students and some because I’m a perfectionist and can’t help myself).

Making materials for offline as well as online

I’ve spent quite a lot of time making text resources because these transfer a bit easier to students with limited internet access, and some things are just easier to explain in text than in a video. I’ve used R-markdown to create this text content, because it allows me to create both html and pdf documents. I’ve structured my course so that each small topic comes with text online, generally with some exercises, and then has an associated downloadable pdf document that contains all of the information from the online activity.

Since the online text contains embedded exercises. I want to encourage the students to work through these. I’ve done this firstly by setting activity completion on the online materials but not on the downloadable materials; and secondly by restricting access to the downloadable materials until the online activity has been attempted (though if a student were unable to access the online activity I would provide access to the PDF document). The image below shows this for one of my activities in week 3.

Consistent but not consistent

I’ve tried to keep a fairly consistent weekly structure, with each week being visually similar to each other. Each week starts with a description of the learning objectives, followed by the materials and links to the live zoom sessions that are available each week (see below).

The end of the week is also pretty consistent, and consists of the student reflection exercise discussed in one of my previous posts, as well as a weekly formative assessment in the form of either a quiz or a submission as shown below.

During the week the students will work through a number of activities (I’m aiming for somewhere between 6 and 10). Those which contain a lot of information are contained in lessons and those which contain smaller (but no less important) points are contained within pages as demonstrated below.

Within these activities I have tried to give a bit of variety. There are large elements of text and examples, which are interspersed with the occasional video where I think these are useful. These will also contain some sort of associated activity, be that an online programming activity, or an interactive H5P activity.

Overall the goal is to be consistent, though not so consistent that the students get bored.

Formatting

Something that I’ve found myself enjoying quite a bit recently (and something that I’ve become a bit obsessive about) is formatting my materials nicely in MyPlace/Moodle. As I mentioned, I have been using R-markdown to produce HTML materials. I then use the output from that and copy it into the html editor within MyPlace - this is a bit hidden you need to click on the button for more options and then click on the button with </> shown on it.

One thing to not about this is that MyPlace has been created so that it is difficult to tamper with the themes, which means that it is hit-or-miss whether CSS will work. So I’ve had to do the formatting old school and use the style attribute of various HTML tags. I’ve saved the commonly used styles into a text document to make this a bit easier. I have styles for the following:

Code and output blocks

blockquotes

Information/Instruction Boxes

I have also elected to change the default inline code colour for better accessibility.

Video Editing

The final thing that I have been doing over the past few weeks is editing video. I’ve used zoom to record since it’s easy to get a video of both your face and a shared screen (be that slides or R). You can download a video that contains the shared screen alongside you speaking in a shared box, but I wasn’t particularly keen on that. My perfectionist tendencies kicked in here and I decided to try my hand at video editing, so that I could edit out my mistakes and edit together the video stream with my face in it and the video stream showing the shared screen. I’ve been using shotcut which is free and also relatively straightforward once you get the hang of it!

item.title: Providing Valuable Feedback Online
item.description:
In my last post I was thinking about how to get useful feedback from students by asking them to reflect on their learning once a week. This week I’m going to make a note on the mechanisms that I have put in place for students to get feedback on their own work.

The trickiest part of this for me has been trying to balance giving valuable and insightful feedback with maintaining a reasonable work load. Initially I had thought about asking students to submit an assignment each week that I would mark and give back to them, but it was pointed out by one of my colleagues that this would be a lot of work for me each week. I’ve tried to find something that falls somewhere in the middle of that balance, with a mixture of opportunities for automated feedback and more personalised feedback, as well as assessment being provided in multiple different forms.

This article highlights the importance of allowing students space to reflect on their learning (which I’m doing), as well as providing various mechanisms for feedback. With that in mind I am proposing three main broad opportunities for feedback which I’ve described below. Each of these broad categories will have multiple activity types associated with them.

Weekly Q&A Forums & Email

I’m planning on highlighting the forums and e-mail correspondence as opportunities for feedback this year. In my experience (and from speaking to some of my colleagues) students often think of feedback as being comments on a submitted piece of work, rather than responses to questions about their work.

I want these activites (although primarily the Q&A forums) to be seen as a mechanism for feedback as well as a study resource. I think that this may help to encourage the students to participate in the Q&A forum. I also want to encourage students to participate in these by answering each others questions, although I am less optimistic about this, based on my own experiences and those of my colleagues. I want to do some further reading on the subject, so watch this space for a blog post about using forums in online learning!

Activities Built into Content

I have chosen to structure my material in a “see one do one” format, where the students will be given some information and will then be given a related task to do. The plan is that these will take the form of multiple choice quizzes, interactive elements powered by either Shiny or H5P or an interactive programming exercise. I currently use Datacamp Lite, but am hoping to transition to learnr tutorials…I’m just waiting on the neccesary infrastructure to be in place.

Within these elements, I want to make the feedback as valuable as possible. With that in mind it is key that the students get more than just whether their answer was right or wrong. the programming exercises allow you to build this in and direct the student to where they should consider changing their code, and allows me to incorporate feedback to encourage best practice in programming. Similarly it is straightforward to incorporate valuable feedback into multiple choice questions by correcting the reasoning that would lead to a student selecting each wrong answer. This is something that should be considered when designing the questions. This guide is pretty useful although constructing appropriate alternatives will be very context specific. H5P will be treated similarly to quizzes but will be more appealing and will add some more variety.

The Shiny applications are more challenging. With these, the idea is to build the feedback into the app responses, so that students can see the results of changing different parameters (and hopefully come to their own conclusions). This type of feedback is less “in your face”, but still very useful from an experiential learning point of view. These apps will be combined with other activities (e.g. programming exercises or discussion forums), though these will depend on the specific learning outcome that is associated with the activity.

I’m hoping that the feedback provided by all of these will be useful for sparking discussion, both during live sessions and within the Q&A forums.

Weekly Formative Assessment

I’m also building a weekly assessment into the course. These won’t contribute to the final mark, since any changes to the assessment would need to be approved. Given the number of other changes that I’m making right now, I felt that going through the process to add these quizzes into the summative assessment would be too much. If these are successful then I may consider incorporating these into the course assessment in the future. Nevertheless, these are being planned to provide the students with additional feedback.

These assessments will be a mixture of quizzes and submissions. The quizzes would cover a week’s worth of materials and the submissions would be more involved and would cover more materials. I am aiming to make the submission examples similar to what might be seen in the mid-semester class test.

To help with giving feedback on the submissions, and in the interest of balancing workload and balance, I am currently looking into using rubrics a bit more. I have found this resource to be a really good guide so far. However, I am concerned that students may depend on having a rubric for assignments and will focus on this rather than understanding course content. I had a scan through this masters thesis which specifically focusses on the use of rubrics, and the literature seems to indicate that students like rubrics, and find them to be useful reflective tools. In addition to this it is suggested that the use of rubrics may help to relieve anxiety around teacher expectations of assignments. The more I have looked into using rubrics, the more I have realised that I need to learn about them. It seems that to be really effective the content of the rubrics has to be clearly and carefully planned…another future blog post perhaps! I think, if done properly, the short term effort will be worth it in the long run.

I am planning to use these formative assessments as a mechanism for feedback from the students to me. This will help me to assess the impact of the feedback exercises that are contained within activities earlier in the week. It will also, when combined with the activities embedded within the course material and the weekly reflections, give me an overview of the particular sticking points that students are coming across and will help me to address these in a useful way.

item.title: Getting Feedback from Student Reflection
item.description:
In my quest to provide a happy and helpful virtual classroom, I’ve recently been thinking a lot about feedback. I know that it is important for me to give students timely and useful feedback, and I’m building that in to various aspects of the class. I’ve recently been focussed on getting useful feedback from students.

I remember being an undergrad student and being asked at the end of a course to fill out a feedback form. I also remember finding that really annoying because I don’t get to see the benefit of any of that feedback. I wanted to make the effort to change things that students needed help with as the course progressed.

In my regression class last year I tried to collect more feedback, and asked students to fill in a short (four questions) questionnaire each week online. This wasn’t particularly successful - out of a class of around 200 I would get around 10 responses each week. However, I will say that the responses the I did get helped me to either make useful changes to the course material (e.g. adding video content or additional exercises where people highlighted issues) or to address why I was teaching things in a particular way.

I’m planning on still seeking weekly feedback, but I want this feedback to feel more student centred and I want to encourage students to reflect on how they feel about the course material. Student self-reflection has been indicated to help students see links in their studies, and take more responsibility for their learning (see here, here, here and here for a few examples). In the feedback, I want to focus on their own self-perception and their perceptions about the material rather than my performance, again trying to encourage the students to think about themselves.

Feedback Structure

I’ve used the feedback module in moodle to collect responses. The responses will be anonymous, and the questions will be split into two sections; one part that I won’t look at in detail, another that I will look at in detail.

Part 1: Reflection on Effort and Understanding

The first section, which I only plan on looking at over the class as a whole, asks the students to reflect on how much effort they have put in over the week and how they would rate their understanding. I’m hoping that the anonymity of the feedback module will encourage students to think honestly about this, which will therefore drive some level of student responsibility.

This first part consists of two multiple choice questions as shown below:

For the first question, it is relevant to note that I’ve designed the online materials to take somewhere between 6 and 8 hours, to keep it roughly in line with the 6 hours of contact time that they would get if they were taking the class face-to-face. The course is a 20 credit model spread over 10 weeks, so in theory the students would be expected to spend 20 hours per week on the class.

Since this course is aimed at MSc students, I’m not particularly concerned with individual time management, but would be interested to see how much time students spend on the materials overall. I may reconsider this when I modify this course for the second year undergraduates.

The second question is about the student reflecting on their own understanding. I’m asking students to use this as a reflection tool and this isn’t something that I’ll look into beyond the overall class level. I’m also considering adding my contact details to this question to encourage students who would place their understanding in the bottom three categories to contact me to arrange a meeting.

Part 2: Reflection on the Materials

The second section will ask the students to reflect on the materials. There will be four questions (technically one is a sub-question) which allow the students to identify areas that they would like more information, areas that they felt were good and areas where they feel that some improvement could be made. These can be seen below:

I have tried to be careful with the wording of these questions, so that they take me out of the equation and put the ownership onto the students and what they want.

The first two questions are grouped together, and identify the concepts that students want more information about. This allows the students to identify areas where they need to focus their energy, and will also give me the opportunity to update materials where indicated by several students, or add information to the Q&A thread discussed in my previous post.

The next question asks students to identify activities that they have found most useful. This will encourage the students to think about what they have found more straightforward. By asking “Why?” I’m trying to encourage information about specifically what is good. I can then use this information to enrich other activities.

The final question asks students about what acitivites could be (should be?) improved. This will (I hope) help students to identify sticking points in the materials, and will help them to develop an understanding of how they learn best. I am trying to ellicit a bit more information by asking what they would change about the activity. This information, again will be valuable in helping me to identify things in each activity that I should by trying to avoid doing (and potentially replace these aspects with ideas from the previous question.)

Other Aspects of Feedback

I already mentioned that I wasn’t particularly interested in using this to look at individual student performance or engagement. I’ve implemented some more automatic tools for this.

Student Performance

Within the class I’m implementing a weekly quiz, which will cover all aspects of the materials from the week. I’m planning on using a mixture of question types, including open ended questions that I’ll mark and provide feedback on. Within questions that allow automated feedback I’ll provide detailed and specific feedback. I also want to encourage students to reach out if they are unsure of where they have gone wrong, or if their quiz mark is not what they had expected.

I’ll be able to use this to identify students who need additional support, so that I can try to encourage these students to ask for help.

Student Engagement

It is always a bit more difficult to measure student engagement. How do you know if a student has actually watched a video or read some text? (spoiler: you don’t really.) Moodle contains the option to add a completion progress block to your class page (note that the completion block shown below is from a class with two weeks’ worth of activities).

Each block corresponds to an activity, and will turn yellow for partially completed activities and green for completed activities.

I plan on using this, along with sensibly defined parameters for completion tracking in each activity to monitor student engagement (e.g. completed lesson or require a page to be viewed). Since I’m only trying to get a general overview of student completion this is sufficient.

item.title: The Initial Step Towards a Blended Classroom
item.description:
This is my first ever blog post. I decided to start a blog to give me a place to write down some thoughts on my teaching, particularly as we head into a unique year thanks to Covid!

I’m doing a PGCert in learning and teaching in higher education and have now taken 40 credits worth of classes. I’m really interested in the different teaching and learning pedagogies and wanted to try something totally new. Specifically I’m keen to implement blended learning in my classes, which isn’t currently the norm in my department.

If I’ve learned anything from my PGCert so far it’s that reflecting on teaching practice is really important. For context, I’ve taken over a class for the next academic year that has been in its current state since its creation (around 10 years ago I think) and I’m keen to make some fairly big changes to it. I’m definitely expecting some challenges to pop up along the way and wanted to have a dedicated space to keep track of the changes that I’ve made, along with my successes and failures. If anyone happens to come across this and have a bit of discussion around anything then that’s definitely a bonus!

Context

The class that I’m focussing on (for now) is a 20 credit module that is delivered to students across three different MSc programmes. The students come from a wide range of backgrounds, so we have to assume no prior knowledge of programming or statistics. We assume a base level of high-school level maths.

The course itself combines an introduction to programming in R with introductory linear regression. Each of these topics sits within its own five week block. When delivered face-to-face there are 6 hours of live content per week split between lectures and practical sessions. In the first 5 weeks this is 2 hours of lectures and 4 hours of tutorials, for the second half the split of lectures to practicals is 4 hours to 2. The first thing that I am planning on doing is making this more consistent throughout the class, following the structure in the first half to make the focus of the class more practical. This change is also in line with the learning objective of the class, which focus more on the students being able to complete a full analysis (although of course the theoretical components will still be there!)

The class will be based in Strathclyde’s VLE, MyPlace, which is a wrapper for Moodle. So most (but not all) of the things that I discuss here will relate to Moodle as well as MyPlace.

General structure

Within the course, each week will consist of two topics. The main learning materials that would be covered in lectures will be split into sensible small chunks, and each chunk will build on the previous chunk.

These chunks will have some reading or video content to give students information, and will be associated with at least one exercise or quiz for feedback to provide deeper understanding. The lesson module in Moodle is an underrated feature that lends itself well to this, and external tools can be easily embedded into individual pages within the lesson.

I’m hoping to pull materials from a variety of sources, including some that I’ve developed myself. I still have to work on this.

Tutorials

The one thing that I have thought a lot about recently is how to deliver a typical computer lab or tutorial remotely. I think that, given that the students haven’t signed up to an online education, it is really important to still have synchronous sessions where students can interact with lecturers and tutors. Also important since it’s one of my favourite parts of teaching!

The issue with this is that not all students are comfortable with this, and some students may not even be able to access these session due to poor connectivity or limited technology. From my perspective then, it is important to think about a variety of options to provide tutorial support. I’ve decided on three main ways that I will provide tutorial support.

1. Live tutorial session

This will function in effectively the same way as a regular tutorial, but will use Zoom instead of being in a computer lab. I’m planning on having multiple tutors (the exact number will be dictated by the class size) and splitting the students into breakout groups to encourage collaboration. The students will be given the opportunity to self-select their group prior to the semester starting. I’ll then make any adjustments to produce properly sized groups, and get feedback from students who are unable to attend these live sessions.

Tutorial sheets will be available, along with the other materials, the week prior (i.e. week 2 materials will be made available at the beginning of week 1) as is typical in our fully online classes. The only thing I can’t decide on is whether it is best to have a really structured session or a completely unstractured session. I can see pros and cons of both. At the moment I’m leaning towards an unstructured session (as in a computer lab), where the tutors and I will drop in to tutorial groups almost in the same way as walking around a tutorial and talking to students.

Solutions for each tutorial sheet will be made available after the corresponding live session.

2. Live “Office Hours” session

The second option for tutorial support is to attend a live drop-in session. I’ll sit on an open Zoom session for an hour and answer any questions from students who drop in. The idea is that dropping in to ask a question will require less data (and less bandwidth) than a full live session, but still provides personal contact.

These sessions will be completely unstructured, and will require students to do the work and ask specific questions. The nice thing about this is that it allows screen sharing which makes it fairly straightforward to diagnose programming issues.

3. Discussion forum/email

The final way in which I will offer support is via a discussion forum. I haven’t had great success with these in the past, so I’m going to label these “Q&A” so that they have a definite purpose and students aren’t going to be put off by the word “discussion”.

If students still feel uncomfortable posting then I will answer questions via e-mail, and also add any relevant questions to the discussion forum with an answer. Similarly, if any common questions come up in the live tutorial or during the office hour session these will be added to the Q&A thread with an answer.

I’m anticipating that the forums will be populated by me for at least the first couple of weeks, but I’ll encourage students to look to these for answers and am hoping that seeing some questions that have already been asked will give students the confidence to post their own questions. These will then become a useful study tool, since they will essentially act as a “FAQ” for each week.
